When the exorcism was applied, his spirit began to speak and recounted how he, bound by a charm, could not free himself until that charm placed under his threshold was removed. The monks, however, attached no credence to these words and continued with the invocation. The possessed then became entirely furious, and with a wild, burning eye cried out: "O cross! Some of those who had brought him into the monastery thought now that one must remove whatever might be found there; the monks, however, prevented anyone from proceeding to the work, so that it should not appear as if they had credited the devil, or that he had only departed after the removal of the charm. They therefore continued calmly and unconcerned with the exorcism; but he now tore himself away from the hands of those holding him, was thrown to the ground by the demon, and tormented as never before. This continued for a while; at last the demon, exhausted and unable to resist further, departed.

One sees that the ancient idea of magic and counter‑magic underlies this report. What the fingers of the dactyls, brooding mischief, had bound to the left side, the fingers of the right again loosened, preparing good fortune, and thus good and ill kept equal balance. So here it was words, formulas, and the relics of a child that had bound the possession; but the power of fire was to unravel the knotted thing as a counter‑charm. The Church, rightly, has not adopted this doctrine; she has not wished to regard the exorcism and her aid as merely a counterpart to witchcraft, lying on the same level with it; but rather as the higher thing, lying above magic and counter‑magic, because rooted in God; and in advancing unerringly along the appointed path she has broken the one and rendered the other unnecessary.

Similar things have at times occurred in other cases. A woman from Calcia was possessed on the eve of the Feast of Our Lady of the Snows. They took the sufferer to Valombrosa, and Hieronymus of Raggiolo himself exorcised her there; but her demon remained silent for a long time. Then a stranger monk, well versed in necromancy, happened to come by and begged to be allowed to speak something into the mouth (ear) of the possessed woman. He was permitted, and he delivered his speech. Immediately the demon looked at him threateningly and burst out with the words: "Hypocrite and flatterer, not a brother, but a corrupter! How dare you in this holy place, with evil art, force him whom God has not yet forced? You would rue it on the spot, if what you bear on your breast were your work." The monk answered: "I do not fear your threats!" The demon then formally challenged him, and the challenge ran to the Alps or elsewhere, wherever it pleased him; "you will not reach Perusium without having felt my power!" When the monk on his journey had come to the Perusinian lake, he sat down, weary, beneath an olive tree on the bank of the water. In a short while a black vapor and smoke rose from the waves, wrapped him completely in night and shape, and then lifted itself into the air. The monk died, probably of fright, in Perusium. (The word he had spoken into the woman's ear was probably the formula: Exi daemon quia Ephimolei tibi praecipiunt!) For, according to necromantic tradition, these words have the power, in distinguishing possession from falling sickness, to act healingly upon it. If the possessed person falls, having heard the formula, and drops senseless, but after some time rises again and relates what has just happened --- proclaiming things true and unknown --- then he ought to be freed; but if nothing of the kind occurs, then it is the falling sickness that is afflicting him. In the Rhaetian Alps, about twelve years earlier, there was a pious priest who, being summoned to administer the sacrament of the Eucharist to a sick man and the road being long, mounted a horse and, after hanging the pyx with the sacrament about his neck, rode on his way. After riding for a while someone met him who invited him to dismount from the horse so that, in his company, he might witness a wonderful spectacle. The parish priest, out of curiosity, imprudently followed the invitation, and had hardly alighted from his horse when he felt himself borne through the air with his companion. After a short while they stood on the summit of an exceedingly high mountain, in a wide, exceedingly lovely plain, bordered by the noblest trees and enclosed by dreadful rocks. Beneath the trees they found ring-dances winding and divers sorts of games, tables laden with costly foods; they heard sounds and songs full of every loveliness; whatever could delight the mind and gladden the heart was present there in abundance. \[Page 23\]

The simple, good clergyman, astonished at the unexpected sight, and, from wonder, daring neither to speak nor to move, stood there as if stunned and out of his senses. Then the companion who had brought him said: would he not venerate the queen present, and visit her with a gift? She sat on a high throne, dressed in royal adornment; all those present approached her, two or four at a time and in perfect order prostrating themselves before her, and paying her homage while presenting gifts. The clergyman, when he thus perceived her in the radiance of her glory, surrounded by many, believed: it was the Mother of the Lord, the Queen of Heaven and Earth; and he had no inkling that anything demonic was hidden behind her. Soon after my husband had to travel to Germany, and two weeks after his departure a great terror came upon our house. A young man, called Jakob, a nephew of my husband, began to be beset with fear by the spirit of temptation. For when he went to bed at evening he began to lament and to cry, and said he could not sleep in his room because of the demon and the ghosts. So we made his bed in ours; but when he lay down there he began again to bewail himself; and when we ran to him his whole bed trembled; and the boy's eyelids were so widely torn apart that they could not be closed or brought together by anyone; his mouth, however, was so tightly shut that no one could open it. After he at last came to himself and began to speak, we asked him how he was. He answered: God knows it; to me it is unknown. At last sleep came over him, so that he rested the remainder of the night, and slept until the tenth hour on the following day. On rising, however, he looked so corpse-pale and emaciated that it was a terror to all. That evening, as he stood at the table during supper, I said to him: Take something to eat, Jakob! Lie down, and commend yourself to God's protection, so that you do not again behave as on that accursed night, whereby we all were thrown into terror, and finally must leave the house! As I spoke these words, the doors of the chamber and the kitchen were torn open of themselves, and so violently that they struck against the walls; the youth, however, was torn from the room into the hall, where he was raised two ells high into the air, hanging suspended; without anyone present who supported him or held him aloft. His arms were stretched up, his eyes wide open, his mouth drawn together, his chin twitched up and down as if it were about to be torn off. \[Page 82\]

We tried with all our strength, grasping him by hands and feet, to pull the one hovering down; but the limbs hung so motionless that we could not even shift him or move him from the spot. We therefore all, kneeling in the hall, called to God that He would remember His mercy. Then the youth was released and set again upon the ground. But his mouth was still closed so that he could not speak, until we made him vomit with a silver spoon. Then he sighed, and his tongue was loosened, and his speech restored; and when we asked him how he was, he said: I hope that, with God's help, I will now grow better; for when you called to God on your knees, he went away, and moved from the well to the wood-pile. When I asked, "Who has gone?" he answered, "Satan." When I further asked whether he had then bound himself to Satan, he burst into tears and said, "You do me a great wrong, mother, in holding me capable of such a crime; my years have not taught me such things!"

While he spoke thus, a great noise was heard in the entry-hall, and a monstrous voice was heard, which however no one understood. The young man said: it is the voice of Satan, who speaks with him. At that moment a great fire flared up in the entry-hall, running about here and there. The young man said: Satan had spat the fire from his throat. We then took him into the room and read to him from God's Word until two o'clock after midnight, whereupon sleep at last came upon him, which lasted until the eleventh hour the next morning. He was, however, soon assailed again, and the terrors in our house increased day by day; all the more because I kept the matter secret until my husband's return. In Holy Week, 1836, three brothers of Protestant confession came from Rheinbischofsheim in the Grand Duchy of Baden --- Jakob, David and Friedrich --- bearing a letter from a Catholic parish priest from the Lower-Rhine Alsace, who recommended them for exorcistic treatment because they, their younger sister, and their whole household were continually tormented by evil spirits. From the conversations I had with the three young men in consequence, roughly the following emerged. Descended from common peasant parents and occupied from youth with agricultural work, they had always been healthy and strong. The eldest, Jakob, learned the smith's trade; the second, David, entered service in the army; the third, Friedrich, always remained at home. While Jakob was still abroad, David was one time seized by a very strange condition: he felt as if blown upon by a wind, and such a compression arose on his chest that he began to spit up blood. He was medically treated and was sent to the hospital in Karlsruhe; but all remedies applied were in vain, and he finally received his discharge. Arrived at home, his condition was not at all better, and at the same time extremely strange things happened in the house and in the stable. At the same time Jakob, while abroad, had begun to perceive what was going on in the paternal home; and now the younger brother Friedrich soon also began to be tormented, just like David; and also a younger sister, though not to the same degree as the brothers. In the house there were intermittent rumblings and bangs in a dreadful manner, and in the stable the cattle perished in an unnatural way. When the brothers went across the fields or drove with the cart, stones were often thrown at them from the air. Sometimes, they said, a thunderstorm suddenly stood up in the clearest sky; and on several occasions an unknown animal walked ahead of them and then, at a certain spot, suddenly vanished. \[Page 87\]

Physically Jacob suffered little, but he was a kind of visionary, and saw, as he said, the fiends coming. A moment later the brothers would be as if smitten by a breath, and feel an inner motion that increased to the point of hemorrhage; yet so that, when the attack had passed, they felt their strength restored, as if they had never lacked anything. Often it seemed to them as if they were beaten by invisible but still palpable hands; often as if they were pierced through the belly. They ascribed these things neither to the devil nor to actual spectres, but to wicked people. The seer insisted that he had positively recognized the apparitions as persons still living and even related to them; and the strangest stories were adduced in proof.

They had at the outset sought diverse medical help, but found none anywhere; what wonder, since they sought to drive out sorcery by sorcery, and went to those who were reputed to practice such arts. These assisted them on several occasions by sympathetic means, but only for a short time; because, as they alleged, the helpers were better paid by the others. What opinion I should draw from all these accounts as to the real ground of the matter I did not know. I regarded the two younger brothers, David and Friedrich, as hysterical; for their condition, especially that of the latter, pointed to a high degree of suffering. They otherwise appeared to be anything but timid, superstitious people; so that, since I noted they were Protestants --- among whom such things, especially in that district, occur even more than among Catholics --- I was inclined to ascribe the whole affair to a play of the imagination; yet on the other hand their calm narration, their ingenuous answers to embarrassing questions which I put to them, utterly disabused me of that view.

After I had at last deliberated, and after I had to some extent explained to them the meaning of the church benediction, I gave this to them repeatedly once or twice a day. They testified that they felt easier, indeed they seemed entirely free from their plague. I therefore dismissed them in Easter week with a letter to the pastor who had sent them to me; in which I begged him, in consideration of my ignorance concerning the true nature of the affair, to make on the spot inquiries into the relations of the family, into the circumstances of the people among whom they had been raised, and in general into everything that might throw light on the matter; also himself, notwithstanding the general prohibition of exorcism, at least to employ the exorcismum probativum.

At the beginning of June the brothers, to my no small astonishment, returned a second time and brought with them a letter from the pastor, who wrote that he himself had gone to their parental house in Bischofsheim; that he had there examined and investigated all the circumstances, but had discovered nothing significant as to the cause of the matter. He had had the brothers examined by physicians, and these, as the enclosed certificates showed, had detected no bodily disease. Twice he had written to the Vicar General for permission to perform the exorcism; but the latter had only answered evasively. He had now blessed the house, and it had indeed been freed from all haunting; the half-dead cattle were now well too; only the three brothers continued to be tormented, and he therefore repeatedly begged me to apply the exorcism. The medical testimonies ran as follows --- first, that of Dr. Kühn: the three brothers had, several years before, suffered from pulmonary hemorrhage and had been treated by him; but the prescribed remedies had been without effect, because the causes of the ailment could not be sufficiently ascertained. \[Page 88\]

Secondly, that of the physician Humann in Herrlisheim, who declared that he had examined the brothers stethoscopically, but had found nothing in them that pointed to an organic defect of the sick person, or to a physiological disturbance of the functions of her body as a whole. The brothers, once they reached me, now assured me that when they had left here on their earlier departure they had remained free of all attacks for two days; upon which, however, the evil had returned, and they were again as before in distress. During their previous absence everything at home had been topsy-turvy; there had been terrible noise, and all the cattle in the stable had seemed as if they were about to die. The distraught father had at once run to the Catholic pastor for help; but since he was prevented from assisting personally he had given him blessed palms; and when these were burned in the stable the animals immediately became healthy and rose up well.

The pastor had afterwards come and blessed the house again, whereupon nothing adverse had occurred since. Only they themselves suffered from the old malady, and begged me piteously to help them, since they firmly believed I could. I had therefore to return to the work, whether I wished to or not, which weighed on me greatly because of the obscurity of the whole affair. I had them tell their stories again, I asked fresh questions, I had them set their answers down in writing; but I could come to no foundation, any more than the first time. Their accounts partly confirmed what had been stated earlier, and partly added new details.

I have again forgotten many things; I will therefore set down only some of what I have written from Jakob before me. He wrote: when he was yet away in foreign parts, a man often came to his workshop by day and by night who showed him how matters stood at home; he always demanded that Jakob should throw money to him, and he would show him what he could do. If Jakob then wished to leave, he could not stir from the spot; nevertheless he was not otherwise prevented from working. The matter soon took a worse turn: the visitors became more numerous; they planned all sorts of things with him, and forced him to swear at night; he often had to carry coffins, was himself laid into them, or had to dig up corpses. They crucified him; but when it was over it appeared that it had been nothing.

Naked women appeared, carried out all manner of mischief with the others, sat on his face, etc., whereupon he then had actual pollutions. They would also have carried him off, it was to him as if he went out through his own eyes, and they led him to games and debauchery. Born shortly after the middle of the sixteenth century, in Soignies on the Sambre, she then became a nun in the convent of the Black Sisters in the town of Bergen in Hainaut, belonging to the diocese of Cambrai. In the year 1584, when she counted twenty-five years, and Louis of Berlaimont was Archbishop and Duke of Cambrai, it was perceived and noted in her that she was possessed and taken by evil spirits; and the archbishop decreed that the ecclesiastical remedies should be applied to her. The struggle lasted nearly two years; at last she was entirely freed after hard resistance, and shortly before, in obedience to a vision, she wrote her self-confessions, which we here communicate in extract.

I know that by my father's curse I was delivered to the Devil. In my fourth year he appeared to me in the form of a handsome young man, desired to be my father; and because he brought me an apple and white bread, I consented to his request and took him for my real father. As long as I was still a child, I had beside him another who took care that I would not feel the blows when I was punished. That continued until my twelfth year, when, weary of the convent in which they had me educated, I returned to my mother. From there I was soon again bound out to a seamstress in Bergen, so that I should learn to sew there, where I then had almost my free will. Now my alleged father came to me, saying: because I had taken him as father, I must necessarily live by his will. Hitherto I had lived like a child; now, however, it was fitting that I live as he would show me; and like all people lived, even if they did not say so. If I did not do it, he would inflict upon me the pain which he showed me; if I consented to what he required of me, I should have silver and gold whenever I wished, and of food and drink whatever my heart desired.

At first I refused, then I yielded to him, and granted everything he wanted. Now a great throng of them appeared before me, whereat I was somewhat terrified, because I had never seen more than two or three of them together. They then made me take paper and pen and write down that I renounced baptism, Christianity, and all the ceremonies of the Christian Church. After I signed the document with my blood, they made me swallow it in a bitter orange. It seemed very sweet to me up to the last bite; that last bite, however, was so bitter that I could not endure it. From that time on I have been everywhere hostile to the Church, had a great dread of it, always sought to flee and avoid it, and to hide myself from it; otherwise, however, I have always lived in every wickedness and all sins.

When I had grown somewhat older and they began to speak to me of receiving the holy Sacrament, it was most abhorrent to them; and they tormented me almost until I promised them that, if I got hold of that, I would act according to their counsel and will. First I had to give and present my tongue to one of them, so that in confession before the priest I would say nothing more than what they deemed good. When I was to go to the Lord's table, they had made the holy Host altogether loathsome to me, and had made me abhor it; yet I was to comport myself with a false heart and flattery about it, as the others among whom I lived did. \[Page 117\]

Even during and throughout Mass I ate much sugar and confectionery, to the shame of the most venerable Sacrament. When I then received the Host at the altar, I immediately stepped to one side; and because, as long as I had it in my mouth, I was sorely tormented in my throat, I took it straight out and wrapped it in my neckerchief. At home I laid it in a little white linen cloth; though they wished that I should cast it into some unclean place. Afterwards, however, it was by a higher power taken away from my person. I could not comprehend why people of such wicked sort showed so much reverence and adored it: and no one could give me any satisfactory account of it. My questioning angered the evil spirits; they blasphemed the holy Host to the utmost, and I had to draw up a document for them in which I renounced that loose, vain Communion, together with the false god on the cross. I also cursed the sacrifice of the Mass, and vowed that whenever I saw the Host lifted up I would, with my eyes fixed upon it, spit in Christ's face, and blaspheme and revile him. In return I bound myself to worship their gods henceforth, and to observe all their ceremonies.

They put the writing, written with my blood, into my body; a third writing, to abide with them forever, they kept in their custody outside my body. Thus I was wholly and entirely separated from the Catholic Church, as if I had never been in it. Since it did not at all times suit that I should be able to remove the Host from my mouth at Communion, I agreed with them that they should all depart from me on that same day. For they could not endure the burden of the holy Host; it pressed upon them too strongly, and they held me on that very day to be unclean and unfit; but on the following day they tormented me all the harder for it. Whenever I wished to go to church, they made my limbs so heavy, as if I were dragging masses of iron behind me.

When I entered the order, I once more set up for them a new writing: in which I granted them full power over body and soul; I bestowed upon them both of my free possessions forever, and entrusted them wholly to their protection and shelter. Thus they had almost swallowed me up, and wholly transformed me into themselves; and I could do no good work any more, lived quite brutishly without any knowledge of God; yet they let me go on carelessly and without seriousness in performing what the order required. On the night before I took the customary monastic vows, they made me write a protestation: that my vow should be only a sham; instead of yielding my obedience to God and to my superiors, I gave it into their hands, to deal with it for their favor. I am, they said, not a nun at all, and would never be one in eternity; as proof of this I delivered to them the profession which I had made. Thus the longer I was with them, the more perverse I became. If sometimes good thoughts came to me, they tormented me with many godless things, and I had now to put my heart in writing to them as well; so that they might lay the writing upon what had been written, and govern it thereby according to their pleasure.

Now a cursed spirit came to me, who at first threatened me most severely, and demanded of me that I should grant him alone as much power over body and soul as all the others together had. He also brought three others with him, whom I was to permit to enter and depart my body at their pleasure; in return he promised to furnish me so richly with art and skill that I might confute everyone who came against me. The loose knave then brought me another one, who was called the Enchanter; he had the shape of a Rübezahl, almost fair and pleasant to look upon. When I held this in my hands I saw and knew whatever I could desire. By means of it I also had knowledge of all evil and unjust doctrines and religions in every place and corner; I also saw and knew all their ceremonies and the falsely supposed worship of God that is practiced everywhere; of that one could write an unspeakable amount. To this I was moreover obliged: that, if every earlier obligation should become powerless, the one, strangely written in foreign and unknown characters, and as comprehensive as the others, should remain hidden and valid. They set before me now meals of all sorts of foods, and I held myself the happiest person on earth; in this they greatly strengthened me, and I was entirely willing and ready. After some time they accused me that I had never asked any favor of them; I should desire to receive baptism in their fashion and manner, which I then did, so that I would become wholly and entirely their own. They then took off my garment, anointed all my limbs with a precious oil, as it seemed to me, together with other great pomp; then clothed me again in quite different garments, and I chanted with them their loose, doggish Mass and cursed devilish words. Since they also said they had no power to fasten me entirely in their service until I renounced all the graces I had received from the Church, I had to deny the sacrament of Confirmation. I was now also to receive Communion, in their fashion and manner, from their hands every month, and beforehand abstain for three days from every other food, except that which they gave me. They then took a morsel which had a very pleasant and sweet taste; with that they played much mockery and pomp. They did this upon a high elevated place, pronounced a blessing over it according to their opinion; then they gave it into my mouth, and that they called their Communion.

Against the Christian Communion they spoke blasphemous, scornful words; I had to throw the holy Host to the ground, and they spat upon it; yet I am quite certain I remember that I could never bring myself actually to hit it. They also let me take a piece of the holy Cross; I set it upon the top of a credenza, fastened the holy Host to it, and then said: if he were the right, true God, he must show it, and would not allow himself to be so miserably dressed and tormented! And I know well that I did all this with particular rage, scorn and hatred. I, wretch, held this pious God worse than the thieves who were crucified with him; for I could not once get into my head that a God should thus allow himself to be nailed to a cross. Therefore when I once saw a procession with the holy Sacrament pass by my room, and then saw the people with their many lights and great devotion and reverence, I wondered greatly how it came about that so many people would strive to accompany such a thing, which to me was so utterly repugnant, indeed an abomination. \[Page 119\]

And I began almost to laugh and to deride: Behold a wonder! how is it that the one whom the Christians worship is carried about by men; and moreover so mockingly and always in the shape of a naked man. Meanwhile they set up before me, by the one who called himself a sorcerer, all manner of panels and images, and they placed these their idols aloft with great reverence and diabolical singing; which, at that time, sounded very pleasing in my ears, and then I offered no canonical hour or prayer except what they put into my mouth.

When these their idols thus stood forth in their glory, they made me step up to the first tier; thereupon they raised a great clamor and shouting; and I pledged them my fidelity, and never to worship any other god than those to which they should point me. After such an oath they embraced me with great joy, praised and exalted me to the highest --- thinking they had never bound any creature so firmly to themselves as they had bound me. They also often gave me great feasts, and told me with what unspeakable joy they would lead me from this life into that life.

They were exceedingly angry at the images of the saints; and I had to suffer severely if I uttered my customary prayer, which they had taught me, in their presence. In the presence of her keeper she was hurled from the bed into the room, and with head, arm, or the whole body so fiercely thrown against the floor that one saw the marks everywhere. \[Page 123\]

She could often eat nothing for three days, and then they filled her mouth with poisonous vermin. Once she was dragged to the brook that runs just behind the convent and thrust under the water. The keeper cried for help, and they could not drown her; the fellow sisters pulled her out alive. Another time she was cast from her chamber out of the window onto the courtyard; again she was led to the highest rooms of the house in order to hurl her down from there as well. To guard against this, they resolved to bind her with strong straps and ropes to a stout wooden chair and to lay her arms crosswise in a stock; but all in vain. She slipped her body, arm and leg nimbly out of the bonds without any knot having been loosened or any wood having been displaced from its place; and then at midnight she was led to a part of the convent that is very narrow and to which few people ever come, where, after long searching, she was finally found.

Then for a time she was made foolish so that she knew no one, and constantly said: "I will die, I!" and therefore would neither eat nor drink. Then she fell utterly silent and wept without cessation; at last she could neither sit nor lie down, but went like a madwoman pacing up and down the chamber. When a fast-day came, she could not take any food on the previous day; then on the day itself such a dreadful hunger came upon her that she would have eaten her own flesh. Thereupon, again in the presence of the priests, raw carrion was brought to her; and they filled her mouth with fetid blood and rotten flesh so that no one could endure being near her.

Now, following an apparition of her patron saint, a kind of wall was built around her in her chamber; which prevented the spirits from coming to her past the middle of the room. Soon, in confession, they learned from her the pledges she had made to them, and these were wrung from her by the exorcism. Fourteen consecrated hosts, which she had gradually put aside, were returned; and among them was one with a bloody mark where the stab had gone through. A piece of the cross also had to be fetched again.

She finally relapsed once more, and pledged anew to her spirits that she would never abandon them; but soon after, by a new apparition of her patron saint, she was again brought back to the right way. Now the images of silver and of bell‑metal to which she had sacrificed were surrendered. When they immediately learned also what had been done with the cutting out of a piece of flesh from her body, the spirits were compelled to speak about it. At first they denied it, then said that the injury of the wounded would be mortal if they left her. But when the exorcism continued, the three pieces, wrapped in the cloth, were placed at the spot assigned to them. She was then tormented the whole night with unheard‑of pains, until at last in the morning they left her. \[Page 124\]

She remained free for three weeks or longer, during which, in the last nights, much blood and putrid flesh came from her. An almost strange condition in several places of her body then continued for another year and 23 weeks, with much pain. Her evil spirits were now by the exorcism gradually entirely separated from her. Only one, who had been the first and had then taken the father's place with her, would absolutely not depart. He told her that whatever she had hitherto said and done had all happened through him; if he therefore left her, she would come to notable shame, because she, who had all along been counted a reasonable, sharp‑witted person, would then no longer be able to speak a single word of her own.

This moved her heart and distressed her so much that she threw herself at the feet of her exorcist, begging him to let her at least keep that one. When he refused, she cried amid many tears: "O what a bitter parting that is!" Only when he promised her that he would be her father in the place of the one expelled---whom she afterward additionally set beside the archbishop as grandfather---did she permit that he too be expelled.

Now the liberated woman had become truly natural, purely innocent, childlike in simplicity; she had become entirely ignorant, without any knowledge of God or of creatures; she could not utter any other words than: "Pater! Haus! and beautiful Maria!" With the image of the latter that was handed to her she played like a child with its doll, and spoke to it. They therefore had to take her again like a child into instruction, and first teach her to make the sign of the cross. By the archbishop's blessing her tongue had to be unloosed again to restore to her the use of speech. The same had to be done to all her limbs so that she might be able to walk properly again.

A whole year was still appointed to her as a year of penance, during which she, being exposed to outward attacks of her spirits, had to suffer severe torment. Meanwhile she was taught again to read and to pray. At a comforting apparition of her patron saint, on the anniversary of the former one, her mind became keener; and she then received instruction, in part from the archbishop himself, in the catechism of Father Canisius, not without much wrangling and resistance on her part. For occasional relapses still occurred from time to time; in one of these she rushed so furiously with fists and feet at the archbishop that he had scarcely enough to do to save his life from her.

When she came in the catechism to the doctrine of the Eucharist, she absolutely would not give credence to the truth of it; and it required a private vision to remove all her doubts. For four months she was then taught the choir-singing, which she mastered completely. Meanwhile her bodily injuries, arising from the suffering, had in silence again become so serious that they were obliged to summon the physician Cospeau and some women knowledgeable in female conditions to see whether they could not procure her some relief. The counsel which these, together with the physician, held amounted to this: the injury is mortal; the prescribed medicines, however, only caused her further torments; and it came to pass that within a few hours her death was expected. But after first many pieces of rotting flesh had come away, she was restored to her former state. After several times more demoniac ecstasies alternated with others of a higher kind, at last the crisis drew near. \[Page 125\]

She gathered all the clergy about her who had hitherto stood by her; they likewise summoned her convent-sisters so that all might be present with their prayers; and in the afternoon, at three o'clock, the struggle began in the presence of her patron saints. She faltered and trembled, and behaved as one in the last agonies; she spoke from time to time with her tormentors and answered their words. At times she cried out: They tear me apart, they tear me apart! Then she was again plunged into the utmost fear and pain. Thereupon she suddenly cried: Ah, how will it fare with me yet, I can no longer endure it!

They comforted her and strengthened her with prayers. Finally there came a tugging at the ceiling and a delirium like that of a dying person. When she was asked what she was beginning, she answered: She herself then lay down upon her pillow and lay there as in wide stillness, and the struggle was decided. The parts of her body which had been cut away and thereby separated and set apart were again joined together in their natural places, and all her pains ceased. Those present sang "Herr Gott, dich loben wir" (Lord God, we praise thee)! She displayed many wounds which she had received in the struggle, and showed the shirt that was full of blood; then prayed her hours and went with the sisters into the refectory to supper.

On 6 January 1586 she had yet one last convulsion, in which Mary Magdalene appeared to her, and she was wholly and forever freed. In all these things deception lay very near, and it is obvious that all these results are utterly worthless, if one did not employ all prudence to exclude the possibility of fraud. Let us see how it was handled in this regard. The next suspicion that had to arise was naturally: that the possessed, who descended into the pit to bring the hidden thing to light, had themselves carried it down with them. The appeal to their simplicity, education, and conscientiousness could here give no sure guarantee; because all that became invalid in the paroxysm. Therefore, before they descended into the pit, for greater security, they were most strictly searched by other sensible, prudent nuns of good judgment, and moreover unmolested by the spirits. With them other thoughtful persons, clerics and doctors, descended into the trench, who kept them sharply under watch, and never permitted them to come near the place where the amulets were hidden. One was accustomed to give the searchers a pole with a hook into their hand; and all had to remain at a distance from the spot as far as the pole reached, and to bring the magic to light from there with the point of the hook.

More than that, the edge of the trench was lined with other people who paid very close attention to the hands and all the movements of the possessed woman, and who would not easily have missed any practiced deception. It was advantageous that the time of discovery always fell at night; for now many torches were lit, which, properly distributed, mutually dispelled all shadows on the walls of the pit; so that everything stood in full light, which would not have been achievable by day. The Bishop of Embrun, who was present everywhere, moreover had the Most Blessed Sacrament held over the heads of the exorcised possessed woman in the pit at the decisive moment; in order to strike down any deceit also through the terrors of sacrilege. Despite all this caution, the result was always the same: the possessed woman dug up the earth at the indicated spot with her lance; the paper in which the charm was wrapped then became visible in its whiteness through a kind of glow; but it immediately clouded when touched by the air, and became dirty, moldy, and unsightly. In the evening, the confessor had me summoned to the speaking grille; I went with reluctance. When I appeared, he asked me: how things stood with me, and what was passing within me? I answered: things stood well, and only good passed within me! He, in turn: "So something is indeed passing in you, and I want to know what it is!" "Jesus! my father," I said, "if something were passing between God and me, I would be bound to disclose it! For the left hand should know nothing of the good that the right hand does." He now commanded me, upon holy obedience, to tell him what I wished to conceal; and I said: nothing except that I had come to a full indifference toward all creatures. He found this well done, but warned me to be on my guard; lest under the pretext of the good I be led into evil. "But," I said, "my father! is there something in my behavior that perhaps arouses suspicion?" "I have no suspicion," was the reply, "but rather fear of deception; your fainting spells after holy Communion, the sadness on your face, your silence about the state of your conscience for fifteen days or three weeks, make me believe that something is the matter with you." "Truly!" I replied, "for some time now I have been withdrawing from men, because true consolation is only with God; from men, however, only hindrance comes." "Well!" he said, "I believe you, my daughter, and I pray to God that he may let you recognize the truth, so that you may not be deceived, and that all may end to his glory!"

A case in which all circumstances, well considered, and the confessions of those involved taken into aid, hardly offers any other explanation than through conscious transfer, is the story of Renata Sänger, who at the end of the first half of the previous century ascended the stake. She was, according to the intelligently written report that the Premonstratensian Oswald Loschert, abbot of the monastery of Oberzell, as an eyewitness wrote down immediately after her death, and sent to Empress Maria Theresa, born around 1680 in Munich, and without the knowledge of her parents already in early youth in contact with suspicious people, and thus initiated into various traditional magical arts circulating among them.

Taught by an old woman, she had already begun these studies in her seventh year; a rider had then continued the begun work in her ninth; and in the eleventh and thirteenth, two officers, a maid, and a noble lady had successively joined. From them she had received various magical herbs, especially a root of great power, and a little black man, which however soon disappeared again, probably a mandrake; various talismans with numbers and letters and incantations of all kinds, and learned many arts: to make people sick at will by her blowing upon them, by fixed gazing, accompanied by reciting certain formulas, by needle pricks into specifically shaped figures, by placing the herbs under the door threshold, or by communicating falsified foods, to drive them out of their senses, or to plunge them into demonic relations. Here one sees the aftereffect of the Thirty Years' War, whose terrible dissolution, barbarization, and despair had recently brought forth all these traditions of malice from earlier centuries, further developed them, and spread them among all classes, especially the lower ones and the wild soldiery. In the practice of these arts she soon became visionary; she heard, gazing into the distance, what was secretly spoken of her here and there; she saw herself at the Sabbath, with the change of her name to Emma Renata, entered into the black book, and received seventy years of life promised in exchange for her renunciation. All this was now a poor preparatory school for the monastic life that she, compelled by her parents who were unable to do otherwise, around 1699 entered in the monastery of Unterzell, which was highly esteemed for its discipline and strictness. \[Page 236\]

Had she been endowed with a less resolute character, and possessed less mastery over herself than was truly the case; then this disproportion would have had to lead to a swifter outbreak. But resolute as she was, once she had taken her side, she went her ways in silence, without letting anything outwardly be noticed. She submitted herself to all the rigor of discipline; was careful in the fulfillment of her order's duties, and even knew how to spread around herself an appearance of piety; so that many held her in high esteem, and her convent sisters appointed her subprioress; indeed, they would have elected her prioress, if not a frequent dissatisfaction with her state, often rushing into it, a persistent aversion against her superiors, and a continuing restlessness on account of inner concerns, which she only hinted at with half words and would confide to no one, had held her back from it. This uncanny quality in her being, combined with the dark seclusion in which she set herself apart from all, also brought it about that for many years she came into no closer intercourse or more intimate association with any of her fellow sisters; which in turn preserved these from contagion by her arts, which she ceaselessly practiced for herself, drawing the herbs in the convent garden, and procuring from outside whatever else she lacked. Meanwhile it could not fail to happen that her heart must have embittered itself in this isolation; the compulsion to outward hypocrisy, alongside the secret practice of wicked arts, must have, ever increasing the tornness of her nature, filled her with resentment and hatred. This was greatly augmented still further by outward circumstances that arose; such as when in the year 1738 the provost of the convent removed the many cats with which she surrounded herself---already characteristic of her disposition, even if they did not, as she later confessed, hang together with her sorcery---on account of the great unrest they caused. Her mind, it seems, was thereby embittered to the depths, and from then on she began to direct her arts against those who had drawn her hatred upon themselves. From this moment onward peace and quiet had fled from the community of sisters; and the convent became the scene of the strangest events. Nightly there arose tumult and unrest within and without the cells; now it seemed to the sisters as if coaches and wagons were driving through the dormitory; now they heard in the garden, beneath the windows of the same, an unusual clamor. When they lay in their beds, then they were pressed, struck, pinched, and strangled; so that in the morning they could scarcely stir, and more than once bore blue marks from it; the locking of the cell, the sprinkling with holy water, and the blessing helped for a time, but never in the long run. Once when one of the convent women, on such an occasion, struck about her with her scourge, and the tormenting spirit fled from her after she seemed to have hit it hard, there was seen early in the morning on Renata's eye a bloody mark; which indeed awakened some suspicion against her, but naturally led to no certainty. But soon others fell gravely ill, and it was noticed that it was always the best, and those most useful to the convent, who in this manner were suddenly, and as if struck by evil sorcery, afflicted with burdensome and painful illnesses. This fate befell four in succession within the convent walls; and it was soon observed that the evil also spread outside of them, in a striking manner, to the male and female relatives of the provost. In five other sisters there soon appeared symptoms of another kind. \[Page 237\]

They retired to rest, then they came---without really sleeping---out of themselves; and in this state, having become clairvoyant, they now saw various persons standing before them, among these also Renata; who tormented them in every conceivable manner and way, without their being able to stir themselves, to defend, or even to cry out. On the whole following day they were then tormented by inner anxieties, which especially multiplied in the church; from which they were often driven out against their will, as by an irresistible force. When they went to choir, their voice was alternately taken away and restored, and their singing in between transformed into a hideous howling; whereby the throat sometimes swelled high, and then fell together again. All this was connected with trembling, head-shaking, striking of hands and breast, and various convulsive movements; accompanied by the feeling as if an animal moved in their body; great despondency and despairing thoughts joined themselves likewise to these evils.

All who had been seized by this state were, according to the testimony of the doctors, previously of good bodily constitution; their mental powers were unimpaired, their conduct showed itself blameless. Thus neither in a natural cause nor in a sinful play of lies could the ground of those hitherto unheard-of effects be sought; but no one thought of possession and sorcery. Among the sick was also Cäcilia Pistorini from Amberg, and from this one the spirit had begun to speak in 1745, named his name, and predicted much of the future; but since she did not speak in foreign languages and nothing very remarkable, one still took offense at advising possession. Moreover, one was not sure of her as one who had only recently been in the convent; and that had brought her many humiliations and hard trials from the side of the superior. Renata had been very active in this; she persecuted the afflicted one, on whom she had cast a hatred, to the utmost; and since on account of her age and understanding she stood in some esteem with many, she took all pains to teach those in the convent: there are neither witches nor possessed, and what showed itself in Cäcilia was a pretended thing, mixed with many punishable disorders. In the meantime, however, no one could see what the unfortunate one drove to such a play; one had previously, when her states began to show themselves, given her leave to leave the convent; with tears in her eyes she had begged for her admission, to all trials she had willingly submitted with humility and obedience.

She herself, when her mouth in her attacks spoke terrible blasphemies, or to her shame blurted out the secrets of her heart, and the most terrible convulsions shook her; then she nevertheless never wanted to be persuaded that she was really possessed; she held herself only for one who on account of her sins had been abandoned and rejected by God. In the meantime, however, one had at last decided on the application of exorcism on her, this had not missed its effect; but the states had always returned again, and one had then each time noticed: that Renata had come close to her shortly before, breathed on her, murmured some words to her, or made some gestures; and it had then each time been to her as if a fireball passed through her body, whereupon the convulsions immediately set in again. That must of course awaken suspicion; all the more, since also one of the sick convent women, who on account of her spirit and her exceptional piety stood in great veneration in the convent, on her deathbed had repeatedly testified against Renata. \[Page 238\]

But they still took scruple at allowing themselves to be prompted by this to any measure against her; and instead ordered a general church prayer in the convent: to implore from above help in the heavy distress, and light in the dark matter. The devotion had been continued for about three days; when the mouths of two more among the five opened, whose spirits had hitherto been mute; and amid the most violent convulsions it cried forth from them: Alas, our time has come, we may no longer conceal ourselves; whereby they, as ones compelled thereto by higher power, testified against Renata as the originator of all the evils. When one immediately applied the exorcism against them, they confirmed what had earlier been said voluntarily.

A few weeks later the remaining three also began to speak, and all six now unanimously attested the same; so that, as at the same time the torments and plagues of the afflicted were raised to the highest pitch, and no one could any longer doubt a real possession, general mourning arose in the convent, from which even Renata did not outwardly withdraw herself. The spirits, however, did not cease to testify against her; they gave the year, day and hour, place and occasion with the utmost exactness, where she there four or six, there ten and eleven years before had wrought evil; so that finally the long-spun net over the unfortunate one had to draw itself together. Her superiors had, in praiseworthy calm and moderation, still taken scruple at doing her any harm; until finally the provost of the convent found it advisable to carry out that upon which Renata herself, out of hatred against Cäcilia, had pressed for a year and a day; by requesting the abbot of Oberzell to institute a formal investigation of the matter. This one came over, examined the convent sisters under oath, and found Renata so multiply implicated through their statements, that he could not refrain from separating her for the time being from the rest of the convent.

She herself, when questioned about the accusations, had steadfastly maintained her innocence; and when the abbot pronounced the separation against her, she had begged to be allowed to go once more to her cell beforehand, in order to take with her some writings containing matters of conscience and confession; which was naturally not permitted to her, and now in the investigation the ointment box, various magic herbs, a yellow robe and the like were found. When, at her imprisonment, the possessed were quickly brought near, it began to howl and lament miserably from them, and it cried forth from some: O ye accursed hounds! why will ye destroy our nest? O little love---thus they called Renata---do not forsake us! The confessor of the convent now gave himself all effort to bring the unfortunate one to a sincere confession and to a conversion of life; and it seemed to him in so far to succeed, that she not only to him outside of confession, but also to the superiors of the convent quite voluntarily laid the confession: that she was a sorceress, had learned sorcery outside the convent, and had brought the six possessed into the state in which they found themselves; and that indeed with all the circumstances as the voices from them had earlier spoken. \[Page 239\]

There was now no exercise of repentance, no renunciation and abjuration, which Renata did not repeat after the priests with all outward signs of contrition; thereby showing such composure of mind as if she had never committed any evil. When she was alone in solitude, then one saw her lying on her knees before the crucifix, or reciting the rosary; so that, to judge thereby, a complete change seemed to have taken place in her. But the nightly torments of the possessed continued as before and after, and Renata was always visible to them therein as a helper; although meanwhile a lay sister did not let her out of her sight in her room.

The voices only mocked with their pretended conversion, and in doing so revealed blasphemies that they had committed during their confinement without the presence of a single human being; so that one again began to doubt the sincerity of their improvement; doubts which were later justified by her own confession.

Up to this point, the whole matter had been kept secret and confined within the cloister walls, and in accordance with the manner of ecclesiastical procedure in such cases, in the hope that a way might be found to settle the affair quietly, every public step and summoning of witnesses had been avoided. But the cries and howls of the demons from the possessed became so noisy that they resounded throughout the entire region around the cloister; from one of them they had betrayed to the visiting elders the condition of their daughter, and accused Renata as the originator; so that soon the rumor of what was happening spread all around. They now first resorted to a new confessor; Father Maurus from the Scottish monastery in Würzburg was summoned, in the hope that he might perhaps succeed in moving her heart. Her confessions, tears, and contrition at first made him believe that he had succeeded; but new events in the cloister, and the continuing accusations of the possessed, soon led him to doubt his opinion again.

The confrontation with her accusers brought her to new confessions of ongoing misdeeds, and to repeated vows of improvement; on which occasion she, among other things, declared: how she would no longer be able to do harm if she were taken to another place. One doubted the truth of this statement; for in the meantime the nightly unrest would not subside, and indeed several voices were heard speaking with Renata at night on more than one occasion, and then, at a horn call, she rose up from them like a light cloud; moreover, since the voices of the possessed threatened her with death, and once even suddenly hacked in the outermost door of the place of her confinement with an axe that happened to be seized, it was believed necessary to agree to her removal from the cloister. The matter was therefore reported to the Prince-Bishop, and a request was made for the dispatch of a commission, so that this commission might examine Renata, and, according to the findings, order her safekeeping in Marienberg Castle. \[Page 240\]

It happened as the petitioners wished; the bishop at that time, with some companions of both ecclesiastical and secular estates, among whom there were also some physicians, appeared in the cloister, and above all had the possessed nuns brought forward. One addressed him with these words: Cur venis in brevibus, ei non in longis vestibus? Another jumped out the window before the eyes of the assembly, laughed and made noise, holding onto the window frame, and was soon back in the room just as quickly. Yet another seized the bishop by the arm, pulled him out of the room with her to the cell in which Renata was locked up; hastily she took off her slipper from her foot, struck the padlock, and it opened. The commission then withdrew again, and the scenes in the cloister continued their course once more. All the sisters prayed for Renata, the possessed offered up their torments for her; and one after the other, after a terrible attack had preceded in each, delivered, driven by her spirit, an address to her, praising God's long-suffering, but also threatening her with His wrath; so that tears came to the eyes of all those present. She alone stood obstinate; she did indeed confess the misdeeds that the spirits charged her with, but at the same time asserted: her time was not yet up; and when once all the possessed unanimously pressed in upon her to compel her to renounce the pact and hand over the magic root, she did deliver some herbs and men's hairs that she had managed to keep even in her dungeon; but at the same time, suspicious events were reported again.

Finally, the spirits had granted her, as the last period of grace, three more days; when these had passed, Renata suddenly collapsed in the presence of the possessed, as if struck by lightning, at the feet of the confessor---so that he thought her dead, and the spirits howled triumphantly. She came to herself again, however, and was now, while the possessed were handed over to medical care in Würzburg, brought in secular clothes to Castle Marienberg, and her trial immediately instituted. During the same, she continuously gave all signs of true repentance; but the torments in the monastery and among the possessed would not cease on that account. \[Page 241\]

They disregarded it and did not stop. She was still seen at night, as she with others inflicted these torments; the hands and faces of the maltreated showed traces in the morning, and various objects were found in the beds, which had been dragged from other places in the monastery for this purpose. The possessed were alternately freed through the exorcisms and newly afflicted again; and the spirits continuously testified from them against Renata. She was therefore interrogated repeatedly, and since she persisted in her previous confessions and continuously admitted herself guilty of sorcery, she was finally declared forfeit of all spiritual privileges and immediately handed over to the secular courts: which, after a newly conducted investigation, condemned her according to the laws on sorcery to the fire; which the highest authority mitigated to the effect that she should first be executed with the sword. Molinet in his Belgian chronicle for the year 1490 confirms these accounts, adding: that the evil had passed from one to the other innocents. The demons had given themselves out as angels of light who belonged to the hierarchy of the Seraphim, and had at last been driven out by the Dean of Cambrai. He had carried the Eucharist to the sick, and set the demons the condition: if it were nothing but bread, then it might by no means disturb them in their possession; but if the body of the Lord, then they must withdraw from the possessed.

Wier, whose testimony as a physician and Protestant one may here allow to stand,¹ even if he had the weakness of believing in the devil, has recorded several other cases of this kind from his own experience. In the convent of Kentorp, in the county of Mark not far from Hamm, the enclosed nuns, noblewomen as well as others, were seized by a possession; and the individuals in various ways, some more violently, others more mildly, tormented. In this variety, however, there was one thing common to all: that as soon as one was seized by an attack, all the others, even if they were in completely separate rooms, as soon as they heard the noise, were likewise drawn into it and miserably plagued. Anna Lemgon was one of the older and stout-hearted sisters who clearly explained to the physician Wier the circumstances of the whole evil. It began with her, who was one of the first seized, with pains in the left hypochondrium; she was held to be seized by epilepsy, and was sent to the convent of Nonnery so that she might drink from the skull of the holy Cornelius; she did so, and the nuns now falsely said that she was better. \[Page 244\]

But when she was soon more violently visited by the evil, and other nuns were likewise found drawn into it; a soothsayer was consulted, who gave testimony against the convent's cook as the originator of the evil. Now the malignancy of the plague increased; the convulsions became more manifold and more deeply cutting, and the seized were driven to bite one another, and so also other strangers, to strike and throw down; yet without further harm, since they seemed to themselves as light as feathers, and now noticed that they were not masters of themselves. If they were held back from striking or the other acts of violence, they were pressed in the heart; but if they were let loose again, they felt, even if they injured or bit themselves, no evil at all; so that it seemed as if it had become a necessity for them to rage against their own bodies. She then suffered violent pains, until through the bite in the arm---which did not scar over---needles were driven forth by a secret force. The most instructive thing that has occurred in this way is what at the end of the sixteenth century took place in the Upper Palatinate. On 20 November 1694, the twelve-year-old son Theodor of the pastor Z. Döderlin there, at the church of Berolzheim near Weissenburg am Sand, had begun to complain of headache and stomach ache, with complete loss of appetite; but the mother, who believed he had perhaps eaten something harmful while playing in the garden, had given him a home remedy, which however on the following day had only produced vomiting and stool, with the expulsion of some worms.

It took another six days of all sorts of remedies to still the vomiting; but since fainting fits, heart palpitations, and epileptic convulsions followed, they called in the physician from Weissenburg, Dr. Wider, for counsel; who advised on worms, and prescribed helminthogogic remedies, mixed with stomach-strengthening and anti-epileptic ones. These too were applied fruitlessly for a whole month, and the symptoms of the illness multiplied; they therefore discontinued the medicines, and resorted only to a bloodletting, after which the patient's strength increased somewhat, and only the vomiting persisted. Wider therefore prescribed, on the 5th of January 1695, pills against it once more, as well as against the worms; whereupon the boy for the first time began to feel a large worm in his intestines, and on the 2nd became so deranged that it seemed his end was at hand. But when he came to himself again, he filled the house with weeping and lamenting, threw himself from the bed onto a bench, and rolled about on it, continually crying out that the worm would kill him with its bites. They gave him all manner of things, especially garlic juice, after which the worm ceased biting, and the boy stopped his wailing. The doctor prescribed what was fitting, but the worm proceeded once more to bite, now on the right side, now on the left; and the boy rolled about screaming again, and the pain nearly drove him to madness. \[Page 273\]

This continued for so long, until someone advised soothing the creature with milk; it then indeed desisted from biting, but was by no means thereby expelled. They immediately administered suitable medicines, of which, however, only the Marrubium album drove a millipede out through the stool. Since the tartar emetic weakened the boy immensely, he was conveyed under medical care to Weissenburg, where quicksilver and the decoction of Hypericum procured him three days of rest; but upon that the worm, ascending as far as the pit of the stomach, began once more to stir most violently. Only by means of milk could it be pacified; with bitter drinks it bit furiously about. Abstinence from food and drink brought on labored breathing, swelling of the face, and choking fits. They administered such violent purgatives that it seemed either the boy or the worm must succumb to them; all to no avail. They were therefore obliged to resolve on sending him back again to his parents. In the meantime, someone had made the proposal to the despairing ones, to assist the patient against the worm with warm cloths, and this proved effective: they could drive it or lure it backwards or forwards with them; it came sometimes as far as the gullet, and had to be repelled with vinegar.

From that time onward the boy could retain the foods that pleased the creature; the others, however, it cast back from the gullet. They obtained the judgment of the medical faculty at Altdorf; who, since medicines would not avail, proposed a dissection to be performed by a skilled hand; and since this did not seem agreeable, the most renowned physicians in Nuremberg, Augsburg, Frankfurt, Oettingen, and Switzerland were consulted, but their counsel remained wholly without effect. Full three hundred times a day the worm ascended into the throat; the belly meanwhile swelled enormously from sundry creatures, which from time to time could be felt externally; but these always remained below, while that one alone mounted upward. They placed the boy on his head, and had him inhale the vapor of milk. The worm, following after the milk, came up so far that it became visible to those standing by, but could nevertheless never be drawn forth; only another millipede was expelled. Only before the Marrubium album did the creature show aversion; its decoction always drove it from the stomach into the intestines, under great pains to the boy; which pains endured until it had reached the lowest bowels. But when it was just on the point of being expelled from there, it suddenly mounted back up to the stomach, and celebrated its happy return with some merry leaps. \[Page 274\]

It was equally sensitive to heat; a burning wax candle, the flame from the stove, the rubbing with warm cloths drove it to flight; and it immediately rolled itself into a lump, in which one could feel a movement like that of vipers. If one brought an even hotter cloth near, it fled to another corner. When the abdomen swelled, which happened several times daily, then the strongest man could not press it down; but as soon as someone pressed the head of the worm with a finger, the others, all of them smaller, fled to another place. Rue was so hateful to them that, if the boy smelled it, ate it, or laid it on the abdomen, they were all thrown into great rage and agitation. They likewise abhorred radish, vinegar, and everything bitter; but the sweet was exceedingly pleasant to them, and the scent of a musk ball made the larger worm leap up perhaps a hundred times in a quarter of an hour. From then on, however, he abated somewhat in his wildness; for although he climbed up into the throat more than a thousand times every day, and each time had to be removed by swallowing, whereby the noise he made could be heard a hundred paces away; yet he bit only when provoked to anger, and then only lightly.

They were all very lively and so nimble that, if one did not catch them immediately, they soon ran away. They did not come mixed together, but the like kinds appeared together; the smaller insects were surrounded by the four larger ones, and by some smaller earthworms, as if by a dam; and some of them lived 3, 8, up to 12 days, until they finally starved to death.

After the expulsion of the frogs followed some toads, then 21 lizards of various sizes; the frogs as well as the toads were lively in color, and of different kinds. Meanwhile, some remedies were provided to the boy by a respectable person, which were supposed to be particularly salutary against sorcery: a water, a powder for fumigating, another with an oil to rinse the mouth, and an amulet. At all these things, as at the departure of the animals, were present the collector Knebel, the pastor of Trommetsheim, and many other most credible people. All the objects came singly, under sometimes hours-long exertions; which at the forks were so great that they produced an exceedingly strong hoarseness. The boy now felt nothing more, and the parents resolved to take him home again; but they placed him in another room, and he slept with a relative who watched over him the whole night until six o'clock in the morning. \[Page 276\]

Shortly after she had fallen asleep, the viper returned, however, to the horror of all. Since they applied triple doses of the medicine and manifold prayers, she soon departed again in that light ecstasy which overtakes the severely exhausted; after she had previously bitten his foot, so that he came to from it, and ran screaming into the father's study, showing the swollen foot and calling for help. Some theriac and the anointing with scorpion oil soon restored him, so that his parents took him to church on Sunday. But as he was on the stairs, from the lower story to the upper, the viper pursued him again; so that he hurriedly slammed the door of the upper hallway behind him and cried for help. Trembling as he was, he therefore could not be let out of sight the entire day; during which he then, in the evening, expelled one of the forks from himself. He spent the night in the house of C. Bambrucker, under the watch of his grandmother and constant prayer, peacefully. But early in the morning at 6 o'clock, he felt the viper in his body again, and one could plainly hear it hissing.

A striking example of this kind of progression, on a path leading swiftly downward, is Gilles de Laval, called de Rais, Marshal of France; who, of noble descent---from the houses of Laval, Roncy, Montmorency, Rais, and Craon---inherited vast estates; increased these still further through marriage with Catherine of Thouars; and thus became one of the richest landowners in the land, distinguishing himself not a little in the wars against the English at that time. At twenty years of age he had succeeded his father, and forthwith began a senseless extravagance. He maintained a guard of 200 men on horseback; a chapel of 25--30 persons; choirboys, musicians, chaplains had to follow him, along with a great number of other servants, everywhere on horseback, and for them, as for others, he always kept open table. Rich silver vessels, costly garments of gold brocade belonged to this chapel; a portable organ had to accompany the procession everywhere; his chaplains were called, as at cathedrals, deans, singers, archdeacons, scholasters, and one among them bore the title of bishop. \[Page 306\]

They were clothed in scarlet with ermine, had rich stipends, and he had several times petitioned the Pope for miters for them. At the same time he had mystery plays performed at great expense, or rather mysteries, as they were called then. He soon found those who fostered and encouraged his lusts in every way; besides many of lower rank, especially Gilles de Sillé and Roger de Briqueville. To cover his enormous expenditures, he naturally had to squander his estates below their value; and not one would have remained to him had not his relatives taken the matter in hand, procuring a royal prohibition against selling any further possession, and a prohibition from Parliament against anyone purchasing any. In this predicament he sought help from chemistry, which was to provide him the philosophers' stone; adepts soon appeared to him: quicksilver had already been fixed, but the philosophical egg broke before it could be hatched. He now sought help from the one reputed to be the possessor of all hidden treasures.

Trusted agents of this master also came to him; a physician from Poitou drew his circles in the forest; the Black One, as he said, had passed by him in the shape of a leopard; that he had remained silent was due to a fault in his preparations. He wished to return home to investigate more thoroughly; richly rewarded, he departed and did not return. A Florentine, Francesco Prelati, great alchemist and magician, took his place; and made use of a book from the Marshal's library. Later in prison he confessed how he had several times seen the demon in the shape of a young man of twenty years, who called himself Baron; how once he had given him a black powder with the command to carry it to the Marshal; and how on another occasion he had shown him a quantity of gold bars, which afterward proved to be merely a heap of sand and a yellowish earth. The Marshal on his side had made a contract in his own blood, in which he promised to give the demon everything he demanded of him, except his life and his soul.

He had worshiped him for this purpose, offering him sacrifices, incense, alms, and a feast arranged in his honor; and he sealed all this by immediately offering him, as a token of allegiance, the heart, the hand, the eyes, and the blood of a child. Now an old woman was noticed, who roamed about the country and the heathens, approaching the little children who tended the livestock or ran about begging, and flattering them, while always keeping her face half covered with a heavy cloth. She thus lured them to the castle of Raiz, where they then vanished without a trace. At first it was only peasant children and homeless ones who thus perished; but soon, with growing boldness, the city children too came in turn, even as far as Nantes.

Bodin recounts on p. 249, probably from the records: after the werewolf had in this manner slaughtered eight children for the devil, he at last also promised the ninth, his own, and indeed while still in its mother's womb, to kill it for him as a pleasing sacrifice by opening the same. Yet he did not attain to familiar intercourse with him face to face, and he was wont to say: the Unknown must be a common fellow, that he should shrink from associating with persons of rank. This speech of his, now, the sign of the cross that he perhaps made upon entering the circle; or the prayer that he always spoke, especially his Alma Redemptoris Mater; his attachment to the chapel that surrounded him; the secret resolve that he cherished, to atone in the end by a crusade---these were the reasons that his entourage adduced for why no such relation would come about. \[Page 307\]

He himself killed his unhappy victims with his own hand; their cries, their rattling, their convulsions delighted him, as he strove to increase and prolong them, and to enjoy this lust all the more closely, he would seat himself upon the dying ones. In the tower of Chantocé a whole barrel full of calcined bones of children was found, whose number was estimated at forty, all of whom this Moloch had burned in his glowing arms. According to his own confession, the number of those whom he had thus sacrificed there and in the castle of Machecoul amounted to a hundred; others were found in the privies of Suze, likewise in Nantes, Vannes; so that the total number was estimated at 150.

They were all sacrificed to the demons Barron, Orient, Beelzebub, Satan, and Belial, while the office of Easter Day was sung to them. The accusation was brought by the procurator of the Duke, and the promoter of the Bishop of Nantes; six or seven family fathers, whose children had gone to the Marshal and not returned, were likewise complainants. He was at first very bold in confronting these; he said: he would rather be hanged by his neck than give account to the clergy, who were all stained with simony and shameful deeds. He knew the faith as well as they, and he wondered that the President should allow them to meddle in such processes.

He became, however, soon more pliable, and the censors of the church made him confess a part of his shameful deeds; the fear of torture accomplished the rest.
